quoteFirst: The two armies were mingled together there for a time in such manner that it was almost a question which one was going to demand the surrender of the other. Soon, however, the enemy broke and ran in every direction; some 6,000 prisoners, besides artillery and small-arms in large quantities, falling into our hands. … Pursuit continued until
quoteLast: , when Sheridan halted his troops, and knowing the importance to him of the part of the enemy's line which had been captured, returned. … This was the condition which affairs were in on the night of the 1st of April.
title: History for ready reference, Volumes 1 to 5
author: Larned, J. N. (Josephus Nelson), 1836-1913

quoteFirst: When Madame Blavatsky was more silent, less vivid than usual, it was "because her Masters were angry;" they had rebuked her because of some error, and she professed constant error. Once I seemed in their presence, or that of some messenger of theirs. It was
quoteLast: , and half a dozen of us sat round her big table cloth, when the room seemed to fill with the odour of incense. Somebody came from upstairs, but could smell nothing--had been outside the influence it seems--but to myself and the others, it was very strong.
title: The Trembling of the Veil
author: Yeats, W. B. (William Butler), 1865-1939

quoteFirst: "In the evening I resolved to watch the dhurra fields for elephants. At
quoteLast: I arrived in the plantations, with three men carrying spare guns, among whom was Bacheet, who had at length an opportunity for which he had long yearned. I entrusted to him the 'Baby,' which he promised to put into my hands the very moment that I should fire my second barrel.
title: The Nile Tributaries of Abyssinia, and the Sword Hunters of the Hamran Arabs
author: Baker, Samuel White, Sir, 1821-1893

quoteFirst: His next visit abroad, two years later, was to Italy, and the change from St. Petersburg to Venice is marked in the finer tone of the record. ‘We went in our gondolas
quoteLast: beneath the bridge of the Rialto.... Palaces and churches were steeped in the calm brilliancy of the southern night.
title: Norman Macleod
author: Wellwood, John, 1853-1919; Brown, Joseph [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The two armies were mingled together there for a time in such manner that it was almost a question which one was going to demand the surrender of the other. quoteLast: , when Sheridan halted his troops, and knowing the importance to him of the part of the enemy's line which had been captured, returned. … This was the condition which affairs were in on the night of the 1st of April.

quoteLast: , we were lying in the barracks in which I was placed, in our rooms, on the straw. Each one had by his side his rifle, also loaded cartridges.
title: The German Army in Belgium, the White Book of May 1915
author: Germany. Auswärtiges Amt; Bennett, Ernest Nathaniel, 1865-1947 [Translator]

quoteFirst: de Coustade took with him forty men and four sergeants, of whose trustworthiness he was assured by Duchâtelet (Lieutenant of Cartouche, who was betraying him, himself a sergeant of the French Guards; they had promised him a pardon), dressed as civilians, with their weapons hidden, and surrounded the house in which Duchâtelet had informed him that Cartouche was lying. It was
quoteTime: a little after nine at night
quoteLast: that they arrived at the Pistol Inn, kept by Germain Savard and his wife, at Courtille, near High Borne (Trois-Bornes Street).
title: The Man with the Black Feather
author: Leroux, Gaston, 1868-1927; Relyea, C. M. (Charles M.), 1863-1932 [Illustrator]; Jepson, Edgar, 1863-1938 [Translator]

title: The music of the spheres
author: Grondal, Florence Armstrong

quoteLast: , all the Austrians are rolling off, eastward, eastward.
title: History of Friedrich II of Prussia — Volume 20
author: Carlyle, Thomas, 1795-1881

quoteFirst: The small boat was left intact, and five German sailors got into her and went towards the (sinking) ship. When they boarded her, they signalled to the submarine with a flash-lamp, and then the submarine cast the damaged life-boats adrift and steamed away from the ship for about two miles, after which he stopped.
quoteLast: the submarine dived, and threw everybody in the water without any means of saving themselves.’
title: Submarine and Anti-submarine
author: Newbolt, Henry John, Sir, 1862-1938; Wilkinson, Norman, 1882-1934 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Detroit to Syracuse that is placed in Detroit depot
title: A Parody on Iolanthe
author: Dalziel, D. (Davison); McVickar, H. W. (Harry Whitney), 1860- [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The whole party remained on the top of the hill all the day, and
quoteLast: set out in a southern direction. About one o’clock in the morning they came to a place called Corrinangaull, on the confines of Knoydart and Loch Arkaig, where Cameron expected to have met some of the Loch Arkaig people, who had fled with their cattle on the approach of the soldiery.
title: The Scottish Highlands, Highland Clans and Highland Regiments, Volume 1 (of 2)
author: Keltie, John Scott, Sir, 1840-1927 [Editor]; Maclauchlan, Thomas, 1816-1886 [Contributor]; Wilson, John, 1785-1854 [Contributor]

quoteLast: that I heard a light ripple against the ship's side, and a moment after the creaking of the yards as the rising breeze moved them slightly. I at once went on deck, and my first glance showed me how fortunate I was in having such a first officer as Kelson. The night was as black as pitch: the wind came in little puffs and flaws, and then for a moment would die away altogether.
title: Lippincott's Magazine of Popular Literature and Science, Volume 15, No. 90, June, 1875
author: Various; Kirk, John Foster, 1824-1904 [Editor]

quoteFirst: After a warm welcome from Mr. Graham, who gave him all the entertainment he could without the knowledge of his servants, a boat was engaged to convey him across the Firth
quoteLast: . Mr. Graham did not, however, dare to be his guide down to the sea-shore, but gave him careful directions as to his following an old woman who had been provided for this purpose. But all Mr. Graham's precautions would have been useless, had not chance once more favoured the Chevalier.
title: The True Story Book
author: Lang, Andrew, 1844-1912 [Editor]

quoteFirst: 3516. 'On Monday next, at the end of the first quarter of the night,' i. e.
title: Chaucer's Works, Volume 5 — Notes to the Canterbury Tales
author: Chaucer, Geoffrey, 1343?-1400; Skeat, Walter W. (Walter William), 1835-1912 [Editor]

quoteFirst: I remember that, when I got as far as Richmond, Virginia, I was completely out of money and knew not a single person in the city. Besides, I had never been in a city before. I think it was
quoteLast: that I reached Richmond. I was hungry, tired and dirty, and had no where to go. I wandered about the streets until about midnight, when I felt completely exhausted.
title: The Story of My Life and Work
author: Washington, Booker T., 1856-1915; Curry, J. L. M. (Jabez Lamar Monroe), 1825-1903 [Author of introduction, etc.]; Beard, Frank, 1842-1905 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: She steamed ahead of us very slowly, and, taking up a position some half to three-quarters of a mile from us, stood off and on during the afternoon and night. Finished receiving our coal and provisions (sugar and rum) at
quoteLast: , when I permitted the crew to have their hammocks as usual.
title:
The Cruise of the Alabama and the Sumter
From the Private Journals and Other Papers of Commander R. Semmes, C.S.N., and Other Officers
author: Semmes, Raphael, 1809-1877

quoteFirst: Here at first I thought of camping, as I had come some eleven miles up hill and down dale; but the place was so bare and I was so anxious to push on, being short of provisions, that I suddenly determined to double my march and make for a fort called Rajgarh, and described as being some twelve miles farther on. Unfortunately, I was dilatory in starting; the march, as usual, was longer than I had been led to suppose; the road was hilly, and it was not until
quoteLast: that I found myself peering through the darkness in the vicinity of my destined camp.
title: Chambers's Journal of Popular Literature, Science, and Art, fifth series, no. 140, vol. III, September 4, 1886
author: Various

quoteFirst: Walker found two periods of minimum electrical disturbance
title: Auroræ: Their Characters and Spectra
author: Capron, J. Rand, 1829-1888

quoteFirst: As the animals had got rested up, I thought I could drive them in and save their lives, but had to abandon them in Round Valley, Weber Canyon. Then, on a poor, jaded horse, I pursued my way, arriving at home
title: Life of a Pioneer: Being the Autobiography of James S. Brown
author: Brown, James S. (James Stephens), 1828-1902
